description: This course describes the concepts and techniques available to corporations, non-profit organizations, and other organizations in their efforts to manage pure risks. The costs associated with such pure risks as product liability, environmental impairments, property losses, work-related injuries, and employee benefits (e.g., pensions, health insurance, etc.) affect the daily management of organizations. Managers who make decisions without appropriate consideration of risk management issues can jeopardize the long-term survival of their organizations. The course examines a common set of techniques which can be used by managers in dealing with these problems, including risk assumption, prevention, diversification, and transfer via insurance and non-insurance market mechanisms. In turn, students learn to recognize that the institutional structure of the organization itself influence its own risks and their corresponding treatments.
name: RISK MANAGEMENT

values.comments:
LGST205 describes the concepts and techniques available to corporations, non-profit organizations, and other organizations in their efforts to manage pure risks. The costs associated with such pure risks as product liability, environmental impairments, property losses, work-related injuries, and employee benefits (e.g., pensions, health insurance, etc.) affect the daily management of organizations. Managers who make decisions without appropriate consideration of risk management issues can jeopardize the long-term survival of their organizations. The course examines a common set of techniques which can be used by managers in dealing with these problems, including risk assumption, prevention, diversification, and transfer via insurance and non-insurance market mechanisms. In turn, students learn to recognize that the institutional structure of the organization itself influence its own risks and their corresponding treatments.

Students had mixed feelings about this course. Most found it “interesting” and “an essential topic in life,” while a few felt it was “pretty boring.” Nonetheless, the consensus was that the “course was really interesting, and I learned a lot.”

Professor Smetters “was engaging and did a good job presenting material” and “had a great sense of humor.” One student even recommended that Professor Smetters be given a “teaching award.”

The course had no assignments besides the three midterms and the final. Some students felt that the textbook was insufficient “for the level at which the course was taught.” In general, the exams were considered relatively “difficult.”

INSR205 describes the concepts and techniques available to corporations, non-profit organizations, and other organizations in their efforts to manage pure risks. The costs associated with such pure risks as product liability, environmental impairments, property losses, work-related injuries, and employee benefits (e.g., pensions, health insurance, etc.) affect the daily management of organizations. Managers who make decisions without appropriate consideration of risk management issues can jeopardize the long-term survival of their organizations. The course examines a common set of techniques which can be used by managers in dealing with these problems, including risk assumption, prevention, diversification, and transfer via insurance and non-insurance market mechanisms. In turn, students learn to recognize that the institutional structure of the organization itself influence its own risks and their corresponding treatments.

Students had mixed feelings about this course. Most found it “interesting” and “an essential topic in life,” while a few felt it was “pretty boring.” Nonetheless, the consensus was that the “course was really interesting, and I learned a lot.”

Professor Nini “did an incredible job presenting the course material.” Some described Professor Nini as “amazing.”

The course had no assignments besides the three midterms and the final. Some students felt that the textbook was insufficient “for the level at which the course was taught.” In general, the exams were considered relatively “difficult.”

INSR205 describes the concepts and techniques available to corporations, non-profit organizations, and other organizations in their efforts to manage pure risks. The costs associated with such pure risks as product liability, environmental impairments, property losses, work-related injuries, and employee benefits (e.g., pensions, health insurance, etc.) affect the daily management of organizations. Managers who make decisions without appropriate consideration of risk management issues can jeopardize the long-term survival of their organizations. The course examines a common set of techniques which can be used by managers in dealing with these problems, including risk assumption, prevention, diversification, and transfer via insurance and non-insurance market mechanisms. In turn, students learn to recognize that the institutional structure of the organization itself influence its own risks and their corresponding treatments.

Students had mixed feelings about this course. Most found it “interesting” and “an essential topic in life,” while a few felt it was “pretty boring.” Nonetheless, the consensus was that the “course was really interesting, and [the students] learned a lot.”

Students found Professor Baker “confusing” at times and they struggled to determine “what was expected of us.” Students also would have liked if Professor Baker made more effort “to stimulate students’ interest.” Students also noted that Professor Baker “should not leave so much material from his slides.”

The course had no assignments besides the three midterms and the final. Some students felt that the textbook was insufficient “for the level at which the course was taught.” In general, the exams were considered relatively “difficult.”
